Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: I learned how the Air Force is structured and the different objectives and values of the Air Force.
I learned about the major commands of the Air Force as well as military doctrine and virtues.
I learned about the basic structure and functions of the Air Force.
History and traditions of the United States Air Force
I don't really think I gained anything from this course.
I learned about the Air Force, especially information found in Air Force Doctrine and the Tongue and Quill and other documents.

This course was very informative of the Air Force.

The exams can be more reflective of what was taught in class.

Strengths:  It covered a lot of material and introduced new cadets to the ways that the Air Force functions as a whole.  
Weakness: A lot of the material was "by the book" and was not intuitively connected.
One way that the class could be improved would be to post the assignments more clearly. The readings were posted on WINGS, which is a terrible platform and I could not access any of the documents.

Not much material is covered and it's not very organized, kind of scattered. The midterm and final are on random stuff we never even covered in class because we didn't really cover enough for a big test.
I would have been benefited by study guides and exams more related to content we went over in class more in depth
Yes, this course includes watching videos and participating in simulations; it's very engaging.
I would recommend this course to any second semester AS100 in AFROTC.
I would recommend it to another student if they are in ROTC because it is a required class and only open to ROTC students.
The only reason you take it is for ROTC
Yes, it helps prepare you to be an officer in the Air Force and provides good insight into Air Force history. The environment was really supportive for first-year cadets!
